Implement sociobiodiversity data standard structure based on TDWG chrono model

- Create directory structure following TDWG standards (vocabulary, build, dist, docs, reports)
- Add comprehensive vocabulary with 20 core socio-biodiversity terms
- Document TDWG Socio-Biodiversity Task Group with convenors and members from Brazil, Colombia, and Argentina
- Create Darwin Core extension documentation for traditional knowledge representation
- Document GBIF/CESP 2024-015 project context and objectives
- Add case studies overview covering medicinal plants, agroecology, and traditional ecological knowledge
- Include contributing guidelines respecting community rights and FPIC
- Add comprehensive documentation (Quick Start, Task Group info, Extension specs)
- Set up project infrastructure (LICENSE, .gitignore, build/dist README files)

All documentation is in English and structured for collaboration between South American partners
while respecting Indigenous data sovereignty and traditional knowledge protocols.
